description: Early Modern English (ca. 1500) slang term meaning "beggar's child".  Possibly from Scots bratchet (“bitch, hound”).  Or, possibly originally a dialectal word, from northern and western England and the Midlands, for a "makeshift or ragged garment," from Old English bratt (“cloak”), which is from a Celtic source (Old Irish brat (“cloak, cloth”)).

entries.meaning: (derogatory, slang) A child who is regarded as mischievous, unruly, spoiled, or selfish.
examples: Get that little brat away from me!

entries.meaning: (slang) A child (at any age) of an active military service member.
(historical) A rough cloak or ragged garment.
(obsolete, UK, Scotland, dialect) A coarse kind of apron for keeping the clothes clean; a bib.

examples: They are your Will-Worship-men, your Prelates Brats: Take the whole Litter of’um, and you’ll finde never a barrel better Herring.

verbs.description: brat (third-person singular simple present brats, present participle bratting, simple past and past participle bratted)

entries.meaning: (BDSM, intransitive) To act in a bratty manner (as the submissive).
examples: Ruthie was Ed's own submissive, a short, pretty, feisty ash-blonde New York City native who combined her submission to Ed with a good deal of mischievous bratting and a lot of sharp, intelligent conversation  […]

description: Shortened from bratwurst, from German Bratwurst.

entries.meaning: (mining) A thin bed of coal mixed with pyrites or carbonate of lime.
(military) Acronym of Born, Raised, And Transferred.
